question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really learned a lot regarding risk assessment and mitigation strategies. I really appreciated learning about all aspects, including credit and market risk.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot surrounding credit risk and some more general finance topics that I really had not known about in the past. Our final project was incredibly hands on, and I found that I learned a lot about how to source data.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to measure and interpret financial risks using tools like Value at Risk, Expected Shortfall, and the Merton credit model. I also gained practical skills in mitigating risk—through hedging with options or futures, diversifying portfolios, and deploying credit derivatives and securitization techniques. Lastly, I developed an enterprise-wide perspective on risk management by studying operational, liquidity, and model risks, as well as stress testing and capital adequacy, enabling me to see how interconnected factors affect an entire financial institution.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Know about credit risk with modeling, know about EMMA and GARCH for volatility forecasting, and know about risk happening in the entire banking system.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about various risk management strategies.
I learned about different types of risk and other important financial concepts.
I worked on delivering a group presentation and preparing a final research project based on real-world data.

response_text: We learned about different ways to measure and mitigate risk across three areas: market risk, credit risk, and operational risk.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. Learned key risk types (market, credit, liquidity) and how to measure/manage them in practice.2. Gained hands-on experience with VaR, Expected Shortfall, GARCH, and risk modeling tools.3. Improved group collaboration and data analysis skills through the two-stage case project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Risk Management Knowledge

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to infer default probabilities using the Merton model and Moody’s KMV EDF framework. I mastered Value at Risk and Expected Shortfall techniques, from historical simulation to extreme‑value methods. I built option‑pricing models (binomial and Black–Scholes), computed Greeks, and executed dynamic delta hedges.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the lecture and weekly homeworks proved to be good, specifically the topics touched on. Really appreciated the emphasis on developing a project from scratch as part of the final project.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The weekly homeworks represented the class content quite well. The only problem was that due to the lack of solving problems, you wouldnt always actually now how to solve these problems and would have to do a lot of searching through the textbook for equations or where to get certain variables.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The **case study format** was a standout component: it gave us practical scenarios that bridged theory and real-world application, reinforcing key concepts through hands-on problem-solving. **Industry speaker sessions** also enriched the learning environment by providing timely insights from practicing professionals, which made the material more relevant and inspiring. Meanwhile, the **project-based structure** encouraged collaborative work and deeper exploration, pushing us beyond textbook knowledge into actual data analysis, modeling, and solution implementation. I would definitely keep the case studies, the collaborative projects, and the industry engagements for future iterations of this course. These elements fostered active learning, contextualized risk management techniques, and helped us develop a more nuanced understanding of the challenges faced in modern finance.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I am really excited about the final project! I believe this should be a big part of the class in coming years as well. This would also help in the future for real world applications.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was well-organized and informative, especially for understanding how financial institutions manage different types of risk. However, since much of the content focuses on risk management in commercial banking, it may be less directly applicable for students like me who plan to work in primary market investment or private equity. Still, the case project and exposure to real-world failures were valuable and worth keeping.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: One improvement might be more frequent checkpoints for the group project, where the instructor or TAs offer structured feedback early and often. This could guide teams toward effective methods and ensure they’re on track before major deliverables. Another suggestion is to incorporate smaller, incremental coding or data exercises throughout the semester. While the larger projects are immersive, smaller regular assignments could help reinforce conceptual learning in more manageable steps. Lastly, any technology or software set-up (like installing Python libraries) should be clarified and supported early on, to avoid technical hiccups that can disrupt progress.

response_text: The topic of risk in finance is unbelievably interesting. It is one of the most exciting puzzles/strategy games that has yet to be solved. It is so stimulating to think about how pulling certain levers affects other aspects of finance.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The final project is the most stimulating aspect of the class! The assignments gave me an opportunity to interact with the material, but I believe these could be improved. It was often hard to understand what the professor(s) were attempting to communicate, why it was important and what the key concepts were. I found during the 3 hours of lecture, I would rarely absorb 15-30 minutes worth of content.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The mix of regular home assignments, worked examples in lectures, and guest speakers from the finance industry kept the material fresh and grounded in real practice. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great topics and concepts - be ready to study the textbook or look up online, because concepts will be rushed through.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is pretty chaotic, but there are definitely some good things to take from it. The workload is not that bad either.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a great fit if you’re excited about applying quantitative skills to real-world financial problems. You’ll learn how to model, measure, and mitigate various types of risk—market, credit, operational, and more—through a blend of lectures, case studies, and group projects. The course moves quickly and assumes a solid math and programming foundation, but the hands-on approach, plus exposure to industry speakers, keeps it engaging. If you’re serious about a future in banking, investment, or fintech, this experience will equip you with both conceptual insight and practical risk management strategies.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Go for it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are interested in a future career in finance I would recommend this class, even if you may not have a lot of previous knowledge of finance. Both Dr. Ye and Dr. Liu have a lot of industry experience in addition to their academic background so you'll definitely learn a lot through this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would suggest doing a lot of reading outside of class. If you think that you will learn everything you need just by attending and engaging with the lectures, you are wrong.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would encourage the student to consider why they are taking this course. I would recommend it for anybody who is taking it just for the opportunity of applying themselves during the final project. However, for students looking to learn about risk holistically and looking for an instructor to teach these concepts, I would not recommend this course. It was hard to grasp concepts from the professors and was largely a self-taught experience for me. Given the pace of this course, even the self learning was extremely difficult. The course materials were also unclear and I often found myself leaning on other outside tools. That being said, a student could easily gain this sort of learning experience outside of this class, so I would recommend this class solely for the final project.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're planning to go into risk management, banking, or anything on the institutional finance side, this course is super helpful and well-structured. You’ll learn a lot of practical tools and get to work on a pretty cool case project. That said, if you're more into investing or private equity like me, not everything will feel directly relevant—but it still gives you a solid understanding of how financial systems manage risk, which is valuable to know.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Homework and classroom material are not enough for the exam, need to do more review by taking some basic exercises.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are weighing this class, know it is a hands‑on deep dive: you will do weekly take‑home assignments, work through detailed in‑class examples, and hear from finance‑industry guests who bridge theory and practice. Dive in, ask questions, and you will leave with real skills in measuring risk and pricing derivatives that employers value.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: One improvement might be more frequent checkpoints for the group project, where the instructor or TAs offer structured feedback early and often. While the larger projects are immersive, smaller regular assignments could help reinforce conceptual learning in more manageable steps. Lastly, any technology or software set-up (like installing Python libraries) should be clarified and supported early on, to avoid technical hiccups that can disrupt progress.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a great fit if you’re excited about applying quantitative skills to real-world financial problems. You’ll learn how to model, measure, and mitigate various types of risk—market, credit, operational, and more—through a blend of lectures, case studies, and group projects. The course moves quickly and assumes a solid math and programming foundation, but the hands-on approach, plus exposure to industry speakers, keeps it engaging. If you’re serious about a future in banking, investment, or fintech, this experience will equip you with both conceptual insight and practical risk management strategies.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Go for it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are interested in a future career in finance I would recommend this class, even if you may not have a lot of previous knowledge of finance. Both Dr. Ye and Dr. Liu have a lot of industry experience in addition to their academic background so you'll definitely learn a lot through this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would suggest doing a lot of reading outside of class. If you think that you will learn everything you need just by attending and engaging with the lectures, you are wrong.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would encourage the student to consider why they are taking this course. I would recommend it for anybody who is taking it just for the opportunity of applying themselves during the final project. However, for students looking to learn about risk holistically and looking for an instructor to teach these concepts, I would not recommend this course. It was hard to grasp concepts from the professors and was largely a self-taught experience for me. Given the pace of this course, even the self learning was extremely difficult. The course materials were also unclear and I often found myself leaning on other outside tools. That being said, a student could easily gain this sort of learning experience outside of this class, so I would recommend this class solely for the final project.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're planning to go into risk management, banking, or anything on the institutional finance side, this course is super helpful and well-structured. You’ll learn a lot of practical tools and get to work on a pretty cool case project. That said, if you're more into investing or private equity like me, not everything will feel directly relevant—but it still gives you a solid understanding of how financial systems manage risk, which is valuable to know.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me to translate banking’s income statement, balance sheet, cash‑flow, and capital‑adequacy reports into a single system of financial equations, to set up and solve decision‑optimization models (both linear and mixed‑integer) using tools like Python solvers or Excel Solver, and to structure data for predictive analytics with well‑defined observation and performance windows - using rolling vintage analyses to ensure stable, real‑world performance.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I would keep the initial survey, focused case‑study slides, and regular hands‑on exercises in future years.
